Grammars

Design Grammars

A.J. Vetturini IDIG and MMBL Carnegie Mellon University

This script contains the dataclasses used in the grammar sets for the initial mango design framework. Further grammars can be added here as long as the top level “GrammarSet” object is used in the dataclass.

class mango.grammars.origami_grammars.CustomGrammarSet(numDecimals: int = 2, grammar_sets: list = <factory>)[source]

class mango.grammars.origami_grammars.GrammarSet(numDecimals: int = 2)[source]

Bases: object

This is a top level class that simply defines the number of decimals to use when rounding & control the random seed number of the selection

Parameters

class mango.grammars.origami_grammars.ParallelepipedGrammars(numDecimals: int = 2, cell_type: str = 'none')[source]

Bases: GrammarSet

This class controls the grammars used in the generative process that modify the bounding box conditions.

Parameters

cell_type: string name of a desired cell_type if input (e.g., triclinic, monoclinic, etc.).

call_grammar_function(grammar_selected: str, design_space: PolyhedralSpace, extension_value: float | None = None, rotation_value: float = 1) → tuple[bool, float][source]

This function calls the proper grammar to apply to the active design_space which is passed in

Parameters:

  • extension_value – How far to extend the grammar selected by

  • grammar_selected – String of whatever grammar was selected to be applied

  • design_space – The PolyhedralDesign space that is being manipulated

  • rotation_value – How much to rotate an angle of the bounding box by

Returns:

cell_type: str = 'none'
extend_or_shorten_edge(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, extension_value: float, param: str) → bool[source]

This function calls to extend (or shorten using a negative extension_value) one of the bounding box parameters

Parameters:

  • extension_value – How far to extend the grammar selected by

  • param – Which bounding box value to change (a, b, c)

  • design_space – The PolyhedralDesign space that is being manipulated

Returns:

Bool dictating if function ran properly

pick_random_grammar() → str[source]

Randomly selects a grammar with equal probabilty

rotate_edge(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, rotation_value: float, param: str) → bool[source]

This function calls to rotate one of the bounding box parameters

Parameters:

  • rotation_value – How far to rotate the selected bounding box parameter

  • param – Which bounding box value to change (alpha, beta, gamma)

  • design_space – The PolyhedralDesign space that is being manipulated

Returns:

Bool dictating if function ran properly

static set_seed(seed_number: int)[source]

Sets the random seed

update_design_space(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, new_bounding_box) → bool[source]

This function actually updated the bounding box hyperparmeters so that the volume / other values can be properly updated :param new_bounding_box: New boudning box to be used in the design iteration :param design_space: The PolyhedralDesign space that is being manipulated :return: Bool dictating if function ran properly

class mango.grammars.origami_grammars.TriangulationGrammars(numDecimals: int = 2, grammars_to_not_use: list = <factory>)[source]

Bases: GrammarSet

This class controls the grammars used in the generative process. The methods of this class modify the design graph of the current design iteration.

Parameters

grammars_to_not_use: list of grammars to not use if desired. Must match names in grammar_names

call_grammar_function(grammar_selected: str, design_space: PolyhedralSpace, extension_value: float | None = None, override=None) → tuple[bool, float][source]

This function calls the proper grammar to apply to the active design_space which is passed in

Parameters:

  • extension_value – If an edge extension is being used we pass in the extension_value

  • grammar_selected – Whichever grammar was selected to be applied

  • design_space – The PolyhedralDesign space that is being manipulated

  • override – Used for testing / image creation… manually apply rules to specific faces

Returns:

divide_face(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, override=None)[source]

This grammar selects a random face and divides it into two.

Parameters:

  • design_space – design space that is currently being generated / optimized

  • override – A tuple of indices to override the random selection

edge_rotation(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, rotation_value: float | None = None)[source]

This grammar randomly selects an edge containing a nonterminal node and rotates it along any face by which the edge exists. The face is randomly selected.

Parameters:

  • design_space – design space that is currently being generated / optimized

  • rotation_value – A value to rotate the edge along the face by (degrees)

extend_vertex(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, extension_value: float | None = None)[source]

This grammar randomly selects a vertex that is non-terminal and moves it along an edge by the passed in extension_value

Parameters:

  • design_space – design space that is currently being generated / optimized

  • extension_value – A value to move the selected node along the edge by (in nm)

static get_children_nodes_to_merge(graph, start_node)[source]
grammars_to_not_use: list
static is_f_in_keys(merge_label_dict: dict, fa: tuple)[source]

This function isn’t really math but it searches a dictionary to find if a face is found within the dictionary

Parameters:

  • merge_label_dict – Dictionary containing merge labels

  • fa – Face we are looking for

Returns:

static label_retri_or_divide_for_backout_rule(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, new_faces: list, old_face: tuple) → None[source]

This function is called whenever the retriangulation or division rule is applied such that we can back out of these geometries

merge_face(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, override=None)[source]

This rule allows us to “back out” of edge divisions as well as face re-triangulations by checking the labelled dictionary and randomly selecting a face to back out of. NOTE: This rule currently can lead to very significant design changes as the merge face will merge ALL faces

to back out. It does NOT require vertices to be coplanar and it will remove a significant amount of points and edges depending on which face is randomly selected to be merged back.

Parameters:

  • design_space – design space that is currently being generated / optimized

  • override – A tuple of indices to override the random selection

pick_random_grammar() → str[source]

Randomly selects any grammar with equal probability

static remove_faces(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, face_verts: tuple) → None[source]

This function removes a face from the self.all_faces and self.plotting_faces[‘other’] :param design_space: Design space being modified :param face_verts: Tuple of vertices to search for :return: Nothing, just updates values

retriangulate_face(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, override=None)[source]

This grammar randomly selects a face and divides it into 3 triangles by placing a new node at the centroid and connecting that new node to all 3 edges of the selected triangle.

Parameters:

  • design_space – design space that is currently being generated / optimized

  • override – A tuple of 3 face index values to override the random selection

static set_seed(seed_number: int)[source]

Seeds the random seed

static update_face_values(design_space: PolyhedralSpace, node: int, old_xyz: array, new_xyz: array) → None[source]

This function will update all of the face values in the current mesh with the new nodal values :param design_space: Design space we are updating :param node: Node number to update :param old_xyz: Old XYZ Position :param new_xyz: New XYZ Position :return: Nothing, just updates values
